objects.author: Irelyne Lavery
objects.title: Several hundred Western University students get tested after COVID-19 outbreak
objects.html:
A COVID-19 community outbreak has been declared by the Middlesex-London Health Unit after five Western University students tested positive for the virus.

The health unit expects more cases to appear in the coming days. The students who tested positive had frequented local downtown bars and restaurants.

None of the students have attended classes or on-campus activities but they have been in contact with students in neighbouring housing units, the Middlesex-London Health Unit reported.

“We’re just a week into September school activities and so if we don’t see a major improvement in behaviour, there are likely to be many outbreaks like this,” said Christopher Mackie, Medical Officer of Health at the Middlesex-London Health Unit.

It is important for students to keep their distance when at a bar or a party, Mackie emphasized. “If you can’t go to a bar and keep your distance, don’t go to a bar. If you can’t go to a party and keep your distance, don’t go to a party.”

The health unit will not “hesitate to use public health measures to close facilities” or “issue fines,” he said, adding students need to respect the two metre distance and only come into closer contact with those in their “bubble.”

“The message is, you’ve got to find a way of doing it safely otherwise we’re going to have to find a way of shutting it down,” he said.

A few hundred students at Western University turned up at the on-campus COVID-19 testing facility on Monday, after the outbreak was declared.

“We want our students to make wise choices, to take care of themselves, to take care of each other and to take care of our community,” said Jennifer Massey, the associate vice-president of the student experience at the school.

Massey said the school has offered testing for months, but reopened with more capacity on Friday.

Fifty students were tested at the university on Friday, 65 on Saturday and 220 on Monday.

Western University’s Students’ Council President, Matt Reesor, told the Star in a statement that it will continue to work with partners at Western, the City of London, and the Middlesex-London Health Unit.

“The health and safety of our campus community is a shared responsibility and we must work together to prevent the spread of COVID-19. We know that it has been a difficult few months for our students, but the reality is this pandemic is far from over,” Reesor said.

The council is urging students to follow the guidelines laid out by the local health unit which include wearing a mask and handwashing protocols.

London nightclub, Lost Love Social House closed on Saturday after a patron who was at the club on Sept. 9, tested positive for the virus. A post on the club’s Instagram account said a deep clean will be performed and all staff will be tested and self-isolate until their results come back. It has not been confirmed if the five Western students were at the club that night.

The social media post also encourages anyone who was at the club on Sept. 9 to get tested for COVID-19.

The local health unit confirmed that a patron of the El Furniture Warehouse restaurant has tested positive for COVID-19. That person visited the restaurant between midnight and 2 a.m. on Sept. 7.

The health unit is advising anyone who frequented London’s downtown bars, restaurants and clubs to monitor for symptoms over the next two weeks. Contact tracing staff are reaching out to people who came into close contact with confirmed cases.

Ross Romano, the Minister of Colleges and Universities said students should be policing themselves.

“I think that a lot of peer monitoring is going to be required moving forward,” he said.

None of the students have attended classes or on-campus activities but they have been in contact with students in neighbouring housing units, the Middlesex-London Health Unit reported.
“We’re just a week into September school activities and so if we don’t see a major improvement in behaviour, there are likely to be many outbreaks like this,” said Christopher Mackie, Medical Officer of Health at the Middlesex-London Health Unit.
It is important for students to keep their distance when at a bar or a party, Mackie emphasized. “If you can’t go to a bar and keep your distance, don’t go to a bar. If you can’t go to a party and keep your distance, don’t go to a party.”
